events.name: Projeto Nyan Dino [Qualquer dúvida, envie um email para: amandaoliveirajones@gmail.com]

events.comment: Seja bem-vindo ao nosso jogo bugado! Aqui você encontra todos os eventos (e bugs) do jogo. Comece abrindo os eventos para entender o que cada um faz, e assim ir descobrindo os motivos dos bugs. Lembre-se sempre de visualizar o jogo a cada modificação, por vezes os comandos estão claros para vc, mas não para o GDevelop '^^. Ao resolver um problema, analise se sua solução poderia ser simplificada, pq quase sempre a resposta será sim. Simplificar os eventos facilita na hora de identificar novos bugs. E por fim, divirta-se! Quanto mais criativo for o resultado melhor, desde que funcione. :D
Bug1: Como fazer os elementos ficarem parados até o clicar do botão de start?
Bug2: os personagens em algum momento param de se mover. Pq?
Bug3: A música não toca o.O
Bug4: Os sons precisam tocar sempre que os personagens entrarem no campo correto ou incorreto, mas sem se repetirem infinitamente.
Plus: Que tal animar esses sprites?
Plus Plus: E se começar com dois personagens e for aumentando a dificuldade lentamente?
Plus Plus Plus: E se tivesse um placar?

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Gustavo Marciano
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Set the depth (Z-order) of the instance to the value of its Y position in the scene, creating an illusion of depth. The origin point of the object is used to determine the Z-order.

Useful for isometric games, 2D games with a "Top-Down" view, RPG...
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: YSort
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Create an illusion of depth by setting the Z-order based on the Y position of the object. Useful for isometric games, 2D games with a "Top-Down" view, RPG...

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Set the depth (Z-order) of the instance to the value of its Y position in the scene, creating an illusion of depth. The origin point of the object is used to determine the Z-order.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: YSort

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Provides an action to make the object bounce from another object it just touched. Add a permanent force to the object and, when in collision with another one, use the action to make it bounce realistically.

There are also actions to bounce at a *specific angle* - useful when you know the obstacle must generate a bounce that is always in a specific direction.

> ⚠️ This *won't work* with Physics engine or Platformer characters. This is working with objects that are moved using actions or behaviors using **the forces**.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Bounce
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Provides an action to make the object bounce from another object it just touched. Add a permanent force to the object and, when in collision with another one, use the action to make it bounce realistically.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Provides an action to make the object bounce from another object it just touched. Add a permanent force to the object and, when in collision with another one, use the action to make it bounce realistically.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: Bounce

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOff

events.comment:
To bounce the object realistically, we first separate it from the obstacle. The collision engine will do it by moving the object through the shortest "normal vector" of the edge that was collided.
We store the position of the object before being moved so that we know the angle of this "normal vector". Once we know it, we add a force in the direction of the normal vector, and we add the difference between the normal vector and the previous angle of movement.

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be calculated *to go toward the specified angle (the "normal angle")*. For example, if the object is arriving at this exact angle, it will bounce in the opposite direction.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Bounce off another object toward a specified angle
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffSpecificAngle
eventsFunctions.sentence: Bounce _PARAM0_ off _PARAM2_ assuming a normal angle of _PARAM3_

events.comment:
Check if there is a collision between the object and an obstacle and if so, do the bounce by stopping the object and adding a force so that it goes in the "reflected" direction, using the "normal" angle provided. 
This provides a realistic bounce.

parameters.description: The "normal" angle, in degrees, to bounce against
parameters.longDescription: This can be understood at the direction that the bounce must go toward.
parameters.name: NormalAngle

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be vertical, like if the object is *colliding a perfectly horizontal obstacle* (like the top/bottom of the screen in a pong game). For example, if the object is arriving with an angle of exactly 90 degrees, it will bounce in the opposite direction: -90 degrees.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffVertically

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be horizontal, like if the object is *colliding a perfectly vertical obstacle* (like paddles in a pong game). For example, if the object is arriving with an angle of exactly 0 degrees, it will bounce in the opposite direction: 180 degrees.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffHorizontally

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Gruk
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
This behavior moves an object (like an enemy) for a chosen time or distance, then flips it and starts over, moving the object back and forth, vertically or horizontally.

Note: animations must be facing **Right** (for horizontal) or **Down** (for vertical) direction.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: TimedBackAndForthMovement
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: This behavior moves objects back and forth for a chosen time or distance, vertically or horizontally.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description:
Move an object (e.g. enemy) for a chosen time or distance, then flip it and start over. 
Note: animations should be facing LEFT.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: TimedBackAndForthMirroredMovement

events.comment: vertical mode
initialize
distance has been reached, flip it
max time has been reached, flip it
horizontal mode
initialize
distance has been reached, flip it
max time has been reached, flip it
store current elapsed time (to make sure time has passed)

propertyDescriptors.label: Move the object vertically (instead of horizontally)
propertyDescriptors.name: Vertical

propertyDescriptors.label: position of the sprite at the previous frame
propertyDescriptors.name: LastPosition

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: 4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description: Behaviors to animate Tiled Sprite objects in the background, following the camera with a parallax effect.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Parallax
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Behaviors to animate Tiled Sprite objects in the background, following the camera with a parallax effect.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Move the image of a Tiled Sprite to follow the camera horizontally with a parallax effect. After adding this to an object, put the object on a layer that is not moving, behind the layer that is followed (for example, a layer called "Background").
eventsBasedBehaviors.fullName: Horizontal Parallax for a Tiled Sprite
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: HorizontalTiledSpriteParallax

propertyDescriptors.label: Parallax factor (speed for the parallax, usually between 0 and 1)
propertyDescriptors.name: ParallaxFactor

propertyDescriptors.label: Layer to be followed (leave empty for the base layer)
propertyDescriptors.name: FollowedLayer

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Move the image of a Tiled Sprite to follow the camera vertically with a parallax effect. After adding this to an object, put the object on a layer that is not moving, behind the layer that is followed (for example, a layer called "Background").
eventsBasedBehaviors.fullName: Vertical Parallax for a Tiled Sprite
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: VerticalTiledSpriteParallax

propertyDescriptors.label: Parallax factor (speed for the parallax, usually between 0 and 1)
propertyDescriptors.name: ParallaxFactor

propertyDescriptors.label: Layer to be followed (leave empty for the base layer)
propertyDescriptors.name: FollowedLayer

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Entropy
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description: With this behavior, you can attract an object to another object, such as coins attracted to a player.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: MagneticEffect
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Attract an object to another object, with customisable speed and distance.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Attraction to another object, with customisable speed and distance.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: MagneticEffect

eventsFunctions.name: Attraction
eventsFunctions.sentence: Attract _PARAM0_ to _PARAM2_ at a speed of _PARAM4_px/s if the distance is below _PARAM3_px permanently: _PARAM5_

events.comment: In case distance and speed haven't been set by the user, we define them with the default behavior's values.
Basically, we look at the distance of the object, if it's below the attraction distance then we apply a force. When they are in collision, we stop the attraction.
If the attraction is not permanent, then we need to make sure the attraction stops if the targeted object's distance is above the attraction distance.

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the object is attracted to the target object.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Is attracted to the target object
eventsFunctions.name: IsAttracted
eventsFunctions.sentence: _PARAM0_ is attracted to the target object

events.comment: The condition reads the property isAttracted of the object

eventsFunctions.description: Stop the attraction to the target object.
eventsFunctions.name: StopAttraction

events.comment: In order to stop the attraction, we change the boolean isAttracted to false.
When the behavior is removed, we need to ensure the attraction is removed too.
When the object is removed, we need to ensure the attraction is removed too.
